fields.description:
To have access in Studio and count against the license, the user must be a member of the users group. Although, to count against Confluence license, you just need to have 'Can Use' permission in Confluence Global Permissions.

Steps to reproduce:
# in Studio, add user X to the _developers_ group but not the the _users_ group  -> this user wont count against Studio license and wont be able to log in. 
# in Confluence Global Permissions, grant _developers_ group with 'Can Use' permissions -> user X will be counted against Confluence licence.

Often times our customers need to create users without a access just because those users had created issues in the past (migrations, for example). The problem is that Confluence will not check if the users with 'Can Use' permission are also members of _users_ group.
fields.summary: Confluence license counts users that are not in Studio users group

Ensure Confluence does not run any visible background tasks when it is disabled.
Ensure Bamboo does not run any visible background tasks when it is disabled.

fields.description:
When we disable an app, the process of that app continues to run - we just block customer access to it. This implies that any background tasks scheduled by the app's process will continue to run. Consequently, repository polling, build kick-offs (including spinning up EC2 workloads), notification emails and more will continue to trigger after the app is disabled. We need to ensure this does not happen (or at least, not in any visible way).


Possible approaches (imho in order of preference):
- Option 1: if the app's scheduled tasks are all controlled by a single scheduler (e.g. Quartz), disable/enable the entire scheduler as the app is disabled/enabled.
- Option 2: target and disable specific behaviour, e.g. nuke the EC2 key, fudge the mailserver config etc... when an app is disabled, and restore them when the apps are re-enabled.
- Option 3: most obvious solution is to shutdown the process of disabled apps. However, throughout development we have often assumed that the processes of disabled apps would continue running. This would be a major architectural change.
fields.summary: Ensure disabled apps do not run any visible background tasks

fields.description:
Sometimes an {{IOException}} occurs during a poller run, if the remote side (Google) cuts off the connection unexpectedly (see, for example [this test run|https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/artifact/AGMP-NIGHTLYFULLITEST/JOB1/build-302/application-logs/googlesynchronization.log] at 13:15:12,336).

{{BackoffGDataRequestHandler}} is written to retry failed requests with exponential back-off, but only triggers retries on {{ServiceException}}. It should also handle {{IOException}}.

This can potentially result in failed poller runs in production as well.
fields.summary: BackoffGDataRequestHandler does not retry on IOException

fields.description:
The inclusion of two different user types (Developer and Collaborator) is great and much appreciated. These two users cover most use cases that require some interactivity with the project(s). The ability to open up some or all aspects of a Studio project to anonymous users for read-only access also covers use cases on the opposite extreme. However, there is a need for a type of user not covered by the existing ones available. JIRA can serve as an excellent community feedback and customer support tool (as Atlassian uses it on this very site), especially because the customer support functionality is in the exact same system as the development tools. Unfortunatly, the current licensing scheme for Studio prohibts using it in this way. What is needed is a user type with the following preset or maximum permission level:
- Create their own accounts / public signup
- Create new issues in JIRA
- Submit comments to issues in JIRA
- Watch issues in JIRA
- Vote on issues in JIRA
- Create comments in Confluence (not strictly necessary, but it would be nice)

Because this type of user contributes a small amount of content but the number of them can grow exponentially, it would be nice if they were included with all plans in unlimited quantities as an added feature. This shouldn't detract from organizations licensing the other two user types because this new user type is so focused on the outside customer support aspect. Because single licenses for Developer or Contributor users are relativly expensive when considered for use this way, most orgainizations probably just fulfil this use case currently by going to a different system. Alternativly, perhaps access to this functionality and type of user could be licensed on an all-or-nothing basis - I.e., pay and extra $X/month to add unlimited reporters.
fields.summary: Add Customer/Reporter User Type

fields.description:
If you disable e.g. Bamboo in the a la carte menu, create a project, enable Bamboo and go to Bamboo the Studio header will allow you to select the project. If you click on the project, Bamboo shows you that the project doesn't exist.

This behaviour should be improved, e.g.

* remove the entry
* grey it out and remove the link
* lead to a page where you are able to create the project
fields.summary: Studio header project list should only show projects available in the application

fields.description:
This is an existing issue, but it wasn't picked up until now because disabling and re-enabling the fisheye plugin is not something users would normally do. However, with 'a la carte' this will happen regularly as users enable and disable fisheye.

The problem is due to AppLinksConfigChangeListener not being deregistered from applinks manager when the jira fisheye plugin is disabled.

The fix is to make FisheyeConfigImpl (which registers AppLinksConfigChangeListener) into a DisposableBean that deregisters AppLinksConfigChangeListener when it is destroyed.
fields.summary: Project creation fails when Jira Fisheye Plugin is disabled and then re-enabled

	at junit.framework.Assert.fail(Assert.java:47)
	at net.sourceforge.jwebunit.junit.WebTester.assertTextPresent(WebTester.java:442)
	at com.atlassian.studio.livetest.PrintingPageWebTester.assertTextPresent(PrintingPageWebTester.java:144)
	at com.atlassian.studio.functest.tests.group1.TestCommitNotifications.testComment(TestCommitNotifications.java:63)
{noformat}

The problem is that the test contains a race condition:

{code:java}
private void commitChange(final User user, final String commitMessage) throws Exception
{
    WebTesterUtils.setApplication(webTester, Application.FISHEYE);
    SvnUtils.commitFiles(user.getUserName(), user.getPassword(), projectName, commitMessage, new SvnSetup(StudioFuncTest.getInstance()).getUrl(),
            "Test" + System.currentTimeMillis() + ".java");
    new FisheyeSetup(StudioFuncTest.getInstance()).scanRepository(projectName);
    // Wait 1 second for the scan to complete and for the commit notifications to be processed on
    // JIRA
    Thread.sleep(1000);
    WebTesterUtils.setApplication(webTester, Application.JIRA);
}
{code}

Sleeping for a second doesn't guarantee that the scan actually completed.

fields.description: This story has been split out of AOD-4363. The need there was to replace the com.atlassian.studio.host.common.ThemeProperties.isBambooEnabled() checks with calls to com.atlassian.studio.common.appstatus.AppStatusService.isAppEnabled(Application). In Crowd, the only usage of that flag is in the configuration of the notifier plugin in com.atlassian.studio.crowd.lifecycle.StudioNotificationSubscriber.getStudioSubcriptions(). The AppStatusService is part of the studio-common-components-plugin, which is not being deployed to Crowd since it does not have AppLinks. Even though the configuration of the notifier plugin might not be justification enough to make the AppStatusService work in Crowd, we ultimately need it e.g. for blocking SVN if FeCru is deactivated. If it's not possible to make studio-common-components-plugin work in Crowd, we should split out the needed appstatus functionality into its own bundle.

fields.description:
The CrowdEmbeddedApplicationFactory is being asked for an Appliction which it delegates to the DAO.  The DAO will throw ApplicationNotFoundException because (it's assumed that) the application is still being set up.  This causes some build failures such as https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/browse/JST-JST103-JOBB-11.

This looks like a timing issue in the tests.
fields.summary: CrowdEmbeddedApplicationFactory asked for Application before one is created

fields.description:
The following tests are failing on the BEAC build even though they always pass when run locally:
TestStudioAlacarte.testBrowseProjectPageShowsCorrectProjectPanels (seems to fail on every second bamboo build)
TestStudioAlacarte.testBrowseIssuePageShowsCorrectIssuePanels (fails on every bamboo build)

See https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/browse/JST-AOD-60 for an instance of this failure.

These tests are related to AOD-3520, and AOD-4386.

fields.description:
# Create a user with the "Developer" access level and make it a member of the "administrators" group and the "developers" group, but *+not+* the "users" group.
# This user can log-in to Studio but doesn't have the permission to access any project other than in the Administration section.

We assume that for a user to be able to log-in to Studio, it has to be a member of the "users" group; therefore the above observation doesn't look quite right.
fields.summary: User can login without being a member of the "users" group

fields.description:
# Clear the browser cache.
# Close the browser and open a new one.
# Log-in as a Google user ({{zxu/welcome1}} to {{https://syd-gs-testing-010.jira.com}} for example).
# Select "Log Out" from the user menu.
# Select "click here to log out of Google"
# Wait until the user was logged out from Google. (This can be confirmed by accessing a Google Apps URL for that domain and being asked for credentials.)
# Click "Log in again" and "Proceed to Google login" - we are logged into Studio as the Google user directly without having to provide credentials.

This happens to both Zeus and Unicorn and was reproduced in FireFox and IE8. It seems to be an regression.
fields.summary: Can't logout as a Google user without closing browser

fields.description:
1) Type a search string into the quicksearch (without pressing ENTER)
2) Wait for the results to pop up.
3) Press up/down arrows to select an item from the results.
Nothing happens.

I suspect the selection is happening correctly but it's just a CSS display problem, because if you arrow-down and press ENTER, it correctly navigates to the item that should have been selected.

Reproduces in all browsers I tried (IE7, FireFox 3.6, Safari 5)
fields.summary: Keyboard selection of results doesn't work in quicksearch (selected item is not highlighted)

fields.description:
How it's meant to work:
1) Log into a JIRA instance such as JAC.
2) In the quicksearch field, search for "r:me" (all issues reported by me)
The search results for "reporter = currentUser()" are displayed.

In Studio:
1) Log onto a Studio instance such as StAC.
2) In the quicksearch field, search for "r:me" (all issues reported by me)
There are no search results displayed.
3) Click the "0 results" link under "Issues" for more detailed JIRA results.
The search results for "summary ~ r:me OR description ~ r:me OR comment ~ r:me" are displayed.

The full list of quick search terms can be found here:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Using+Quick+Search
fields.summary: JIRA smart searching does not work in Studio

fields.description:
On trunk now we get a project creation summary page after a project has been successfully created. On that page we have a link saying "Subversion repository <project key> successfully created.", which is followed by a link to the SVN repository just created, but it seems that link needs authentication. If we just click it, we will get a "401 Authorization Required" page.

It was confirmed that the SVN repository can be accessed correctly if we provide proper credentials.

!project-creation-successful.png!
fields.summary: Project creation summary page provides a broken link to SVN repository
